title: DigixArt
text:
DigixArt Entertainment SAS is a <a href="video%20game%20development">video game development</a> company based in <a href="Montpellier">Montpellier</a>, France. Founded by Yoan Fanise, the director of ', the company was most known for developing ' and "<a href="Road%2096">Road 96</a>".
History.
The studio was founded in April 2015 by Yoan Fanise, who previously worked at <a href="Ubisoft%20Montpellier">Ubisoft Montpellier</a> for 14 years. Following the success of his previous project, "", which secured multiple wins at the <a href="British%20Academy%20Games%20Awards">British Academy Games Awards</a>, Fanise decided to establish his own company to develop <a href="independent%20game">independent game</a>s. The studio was named after "tenth art", the name of an award that Fanise and his team won for their work on "Valiant Hearts". The studio had a total of 6 people alongside some contractors when it was established. Fanise's goal was to create meaningful games at a pace that faster than he could achieve at a triple-A studios.
The studio took nine months to develop their debut title, which is a <a href="rhythm%20game">rhythm game</a> named "Lost in Harmony". The game is a collaboration with singer <a href="Wyclef%20Jean">Wyclef Jean</a>. Fanise had previously worked on "<a href="Just%20Dance%20%28video%20game%29">Just Dance</a>", and decided that the team would use "Lost in Harmony" to introduce players to the history of <a href="Classical%20music">Classical music</a>. The game received generally positive reviews upon release. DigixArt's next project was a collaboration with <a href="Aardman%20Animation">Aardman Animation</a> called "". Like "Valiant Hearts", "11-11" is a narrative adventure video game set in World War I. Development of the game took 18 months, and the game was released by publisher <a href="Bandai%20Namco%20Entertainment">Bandai Namco Entertainment</a> in November 2018, two days before the centennial of the armistice. The company's next game was "<a href="Road%2096">Road 96</a>". The game's premiere at <a href="The%20Game%20Awards">The Game Awards</a> attracted publishers who wanted to acquire the company. While the studio was originally in talks with <a href="Koch%20Media">Koch Media</a> to publish "Road 96", the parent company of the German publisher, <a href="Embracer%20Group">Embracer Group</a>, fully acquired DigixArt, alongside seven other studios for $300 million in August 2021.
